Introduction

Decision-making capacity prioritizes the patient's right to make informed health care decisions that align with their values and goals.  Capacity to make a medical decision requires the ability to express a choice, understand the relevant medical information, appreciate the consequences of treatment options, and offer a rationale for the decision.

Definitions and key concepts



Capacity is a patient's ability to make an independent and informed decision about their medical care.  Decision-making capacity is a necessary component of the informed consent process and ensures that the patient can fully participate in discussions about their treatment.



Capacity is specific to one decision; a patient can only demonstrate (or lack) capacity in relation to a particular context (ie, the patient lacks capacity to refuse a blood transfusion).  Capacity is also restricted to the current moment in time (ie, not static, cannot be assessed in advance).



Physicians engage in informal capacity assessments at every patient encounter (eg, determining whether a patient understands the information provided to them).  Formal capacity evaluations can be performed by any physician, although more complicated situations may benefit from consultation with a psychiatrist.



Decision-making capacity and competency are not the same.  Capacity is evaluated by a physician in relation to a specific medical decision, whereas competency is determined by a judge and refers to whether a person can legally make their own decisions.

Criteria for decision-making capacity



A patient is considered to have decision-making capacity if they can:



  • Communicate the chosen treatment option.  The patient should be able to consistently state their decision (ie, without hesitation or vacillation).
  • Understand the medical condition and proposed treatment.
  • Appreciate the consequences of treatment options (including refusal of treatment).
  • Provide a rationale for the chosen treatment option.

Risk/benefit ratio of decision



The degree of capacity a patient must demonstrate depends on the risks and benefits associated with the specific medical decision.  A decision that is straightforward and low-risk (eg, identifying a health care proxy) requires a lower degree of capacity than a complex, high-risk intervention (eg, consenting to major abdominal surgery).



Refusing an intervention as opposed to consenting (or vice versa) may require the patient to demonstrate a higher degree of capacity (eg, refusal of a CT scan of the brain to evaluate for an acute hemorrhage versus consent to imaging).

Assessment of decision-making capacity

Initial steps



  • Confirm that the patient's condition as well as treatment options and their associated risks and benefits have been adequately explained.
  • Formulate the specific question that the capacity evaluation tries to answer (eg, does the patient have capacity to refuse dialysis).
  • Ensure that no communication barriers exist that might prevent the patient from fully participating in the assessment (eg, arrange for a medical interpreter, if necessary).

Evaluation



Assessing the criteria for capacity involves open-ended questions and exploration of the patient's values and beliefs (

  • Communication of a choice:  Is the patient able to clearly and consistently state their decision? (eg, "Based on the treatment options we have discussed, which one have you chosen?").
  • Understands the information provided:  Is the patient able to summarize their current medical situation and treatment options? (eg, "What treatment options are being recommended for you?").
  • Appreciates the consequences:  Does the patient have insight into how the medical decision affects their health? (eg, "Do you think treatment is necessary for your condition?" "What will happen to you if you do not accept treatment?").
  • Rationale given for a decision:  Is the patient able to make a rational decision supported by the information provided and their own values and beliefs? (eg, "What factors did you consider when making your decision?" "How is this choice better for you than the alternatives?").


When a patient is unable to demonstrate the ability to accomplish these items, their medical decision-making capacity is impaired.

Risk factors for impaired decision-making capacity



Patients are assumed to have capacity unless a reason is found to question their decision-making ability.  The following can be associated with impaired capacity and may warrant an evaluation for decision-making capacity:



  • Acute change in mental status (eg, patient is delirious and refusing feeding tube placement).
  • Cognitive impairment
    • Neurocognitive disorders (eg, Alzheimer disease).
    • Neurodegenerative disorders (eg, Parkinson disease).
    • Intellectual developmental disorder.
    • Traumatic brain injury.
  • Substance use (eg, patient requesting to leave the emergency department while intoxicated).
  • Chronic psychiatric condition (eg, patient with schizophrenia taking direction from command hallucinations).
  • Refusal of recommended treatment (eg, patient declines antibiotic treatment for pneumonia, patient requesting to leave against medical advice).
  • Indecisiveness (eg, patient changes their mind frequently or appears unsure about the decision).


Particular diagnoses do not preclude the patient from having capacity to make a medical decision.  For example, a patient with Alzheimer disease or schizophrenia should not be assumed to lack decision-making capacity solely based on their diagnosis without formally evaluating their decision-making capacity.

Patients with impaired decision-making capacity

Emergency situations



If a patient lacks capacity to consent to a life-saving intervention and no surrogate decision maker is available, then the physician should provide care that is in the best interest of the patient, upholding the ethical principle of beneficence.

Nonemergent situations



If a patient lacks decision-making capacity, efforts should be made to restore capacity, if possible (eg, treat the underlying condition, provide further education about treatment options), and then reassess at a later time.



If the cause of impaired capacity is not reversible and/or the decision is time-sensitive, consent must be provided by another source.  Advance directives (eg, living will, durable power of attorney for health care/health care proxy) are consulted, if available.  In the absence of an advance directive, decision making falls to the next of kin (

Summary



Capacity is a patient's ability to make an independent and informed decision about their medical care.  Criteria for capacity include the ability to express a choice, understand the relevant medical information, appreciate the consequences of treatment options, and offer a rationale for the decision.  Decision-making capacity can fluctuate; attempts should be made to restore capacity and reassess, if possible.  If a patient lacks decision-making capacity, an advance directive or surrogate decision maker should be consulted.
